dialogues.speaker: VICTOR

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Thanks babe. Sophia shakes her head and goes back to work as Victor he into the kitchen muttering to himself.

dialogues.text: Suitcase? They reach the cab. She turns to him. Smirks.

dialogues.text: Shit. He runs back into the building as she puts her case in th trunk and gets in the cab.

dialogues.text: Actually, sweetie, I just have to make one stop. She knows where. She just looks at him.

Her cell rings. She checks the ID. Takes a breath. Answer

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Hey Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY BROOKS, editor-in-chief, a rotund, bald, but benevo looking man is talking on a wireless earpiece in a clutte office. He's looking at an 8x10 photograph of Donald Trum

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Why can't we say Trump's comb over wraps around clockwise? I'm looking at the picture we're running with the piece. It's wrapping clockwise. INTERCUT: Sophia has made her way outside the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: You can say it. You just can't state it as a fact.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: It works better as a fact. It's a fun little detail. People love fun little details.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I looked at every picture I could find of him in the last ten years. I talked to his stylist. The hair changes. It's a fact if you qualify with "usually" or "typically"

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: People hate qualifiers. Sophia shrugs as if to say "What do you want me to say?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are the facts.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Yeah well your facts are getting in the way of my fun. Bobby sets the picture aside. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Hey. While I have you. I wanted to talk you about something... Sophia is pacing now. She's visibly nervous - like she's debating whether or not to just get off the phone.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Talk.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Well. I was thinking. Since I'm going to Italy already. Maybe I could try doing a travel piece or something as a feature or--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I have writers that do travel features. You don't do travel features. You do fact checking.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know. I just. I was thinking I could try something new.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Why do you want to try something new? You're good at fact checking. Too good. Bobby's Assistant hurries out to answer a ringing phone.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I feel like I can contribute more--

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You contribute plenty. My writers count on you. They can't do what they do unless you do what you do. You're good at something, be happy for that, be grateful for it, a lot of people are good at nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Yeah. I guess. It's just--  His Assistant signals that Bobby needs to take the call.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Keep swinging in your wheelhouse. You'll get more hits. She sighs - deflated. Bobby suddenly remembers something.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Oh and I need a table at Babbo this Friday. Can you take care of it?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Seriously Bobby. You do know that you have a new assistant?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I do. But she doesn't know the Maitre d'. You do. You got it?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You're one in a million kid. He rolls to that waiting call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia sits staring out the window, lost in her thoughts. Victor gets in, breathless and excited.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Verona here we come. He notices Sophia not sharing his enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What's wrong? Sophia just kind of shakes her head as if to say "nothing

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What'd Bobby want?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: To argue about which direction Trump's comb over wraps.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Counter clockwise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He still treats me like I'm his assistant. He'll always treat me like I'm his assistant.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: It's not that bad. He values you. Hey, you've got job security right? She just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Right. Content he's made her feel better Victor dives back into Gourmet Magazine. They ride in silence. Until.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I took the job because I thought it'd be a stepping stone... to features, or covers, or something. But there are no steps, there are no stones, there's just Donald Trump's hair. She sighs - a sigh that's looking for reassurance.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: You know you could always come work with me at the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I know. And I appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: You'd be great in fine dining.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: So I've been told... by you.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: You would be. You're beautiful, smart, funny. You could run the place if you wanted. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: You just said I was beautiful. You never tell me I'm beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: You know you're beautiful.  He puts an arm around her and pulls her towards him.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Come on. Cheer up. Just forget it. That's why we're going to Italy right? To forget everything... the magazine, the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: We're going to Verona to meet the suppliers for your restaurant. How are we supposed to forget about it?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: It's not just gonna be about the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: It's fine.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: It's not just gonna be about the restaurant. We're gonna relax, see the sights, shop the stores, it won't just be about the restaurant, I promise. It's gonna be great... Sophia wants to believe him but still looks skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: We're going to the home of Romeo and Juliet. How romantic is that?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Didn't exactly work out for them though did it?

dialogues.text: A street that embodies true Verona, hidden away from the worn tourist routes. A small restaurant runs down one sid the street with tables filled with LOCALS eating lunch. Sophia sits on the balcony of a rented apartment just abo this restaurant. She's reading a guide book to Verona whi occasionally looking down on life in the street below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia walks in from the balcony looking at her guide boo just as Victor comes out of the bathroom drying his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I think we should start with the Verona Arena then head over to the Museo Castelvecchio... Victor takes the guide book from her, tosses it on the be

dialogues.text: No, no, no, no, what are you doing? That stuff's for tourists. To discover the true heart and soul of any country, first you have to indulge in it's smells and tastes. She just looks at him. Sometimes he's so full of it.

dialogues.text: Victor and the Viticoltore pose with their glasses raised toast for Sophia who prepares to take their picture. As her camera flashes we cut to the STILL PHOTO itself.

dialogues.text: I know, I know, I'm on fire. She has a thought. Then takes out her cell and steps outs

dialogues.text: Bobby Brooks. INTERCUT: Sophia just outside the shack of ham on her cel

dialogues.text: Sophia sits at table on the patio by herself sipping coff The town bustles around her. She's got her laptop open. A blank note book open beside that. She stares disdainfully at the blinking cursor on a blank word document as if willing it to inspire her. She finishes her coffee and looks around at the LOCALS an TOURISTS chatting, laughing, shopping. She looks about ready to give up when something catches h eye through the crowds... A YOUNG GIRL about fourteen years old is sitting on a cur the entrance to a courtyard across the street from Sophia The girl is reading a letter through a flood of tears. Th constant stream of PEOPLE passing by on their way in and of the courtyard hardly seem to notice her. But Sophia ha The Girl looks up from her letter and sees Sophia watchin her. She looks back through those tears and the crowds. T look at each other long and hard. Sophia smiles. The Girl looks away. The Girl's shoulders heave with a great silent sob as she takes a last look at the letter, signs it, puts it an envelope then disappears through the courtyard entrance. Sophia watches her go. A beat of consideration. Then she packs up her laptop, puts money on the table and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia enters a strange, eerily quiet scene. This is the supposed courtyard of Juliet Capulet's house. It's become shrine to TEENAGE GIRLS, their conversation is subdued. There's an atmosphere of almost religious reverence. Sophia walks past a group of girls looking up at The Balc Another group gazes upon the Statue of Juliet - her left breast polished from years of superstitious touching. Sophia finally comes upon the girl from the street, so desperate yet so full of hope. She's standing before a wa that's covered in envelopes and letters.  14. Some are wedged between bricks, others are held in place chewing gum, but all are addressed to the same name: "Jul Sophia watches as the girl finds a place for her letter. leaves it and turns to go. The girl is wiping away tears she passes Sophia on her way out of the courtyard. Their meet.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Are you OK? The girl either doesn't understand her or has no interest discussing her problems with a stranger. She leaves witho word. Sophia watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA 0/S
dialogues.text: Her heart is broken. Sophia turns to find a pretty Italian woman in her twenti who just watched that whole exchange. She is BELLA.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Do you know her? Bella shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: How do you know her heart's broken? Nods to her letter on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: She wrote to Juliet.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: When your leg is broken, you go to the doctor. When your heart is broken, you come to Juliet. Bella approaches the wall. Sophia follows her. She looks the dozens of proclamations of love and longing.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: There are so many of them.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: It's like this every day.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Why do they do it?  15.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: They want answers.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: That they'll never get.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Says who? And with that she starts collecting the letters, beginnin with the girl's from the street. Sophia is startled at this intrusion, it doesn't seem rig

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Hey. Whoa. Wait. What are you doing? You can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Why can't I?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Because it's like taking pennies out of a wishing well or something, these are people's wishes, you can't just take people's wishes.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: But then how are we supposed to give them answers? This throws Sophia. She gives Bella an inquiring look.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Who's we?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Come. I'll show you. They walk out of the courtyard and across an alley to a restaurant. Sophia looks up and sees that it's called: "Lettere a Giulietta".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bella walks through the restaurant into the kitchen. Soph follows. The kitchen is very busy. In the middle of it al the head chef, ANGELINA, a round woman in her sixties wit no nonsense air about her. She's barking orders at her st when Bella and Sophia approach. (Italian in Italics)  16.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Mama, this is Sophia, I'm just gonna show her upstairs. Angelina smiles at Sophia. Sophia smiles back. Angelina l at the basket of letters Bella is carrying.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELINA
dialogues.text: Looks like you'll be having a busy night. Bella nods then turns to Sophia.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: This way. They walk through the kitchen and up some stairs into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a small modern-looking office just above the restaur Big arching windows overlook a courtyard, Posters on the show scenes from "Romeo and Juliet" movies of the past. There are desks and filing cabinets and computers. Three friendly-looking WOMEN look up as Sophia and Bella walk i

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Ladies, this is Sophia. Sophia kind of half waves at the smiling women.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: These are The Secretaries of Juliet. We respond to the letters she receives from around the world.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: You mean you actually write back? To everyone? Bella smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: We give answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bella leads Sophia on a tour of the office.  17.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: So? How do you decide which of you answers which letter?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: We all have our areas of expertise. They pass a kindly looking woman in her seventies, MARIA.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Maria has been happily married for fifty-one years so she tends to handle mostly marital issues... At the next desk is a bookish woman in her late fifties w has the air of someone who has seen it all, FRANCESCA.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Francesca made her living as a nurse so she usually does illness and caring for the sick... Lastly they approach an diminutive elderly woman reading letter and slowly shaking her head, DONATELLA.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Donatella has twelve children, twenty-seven grandchildren, and six great grandchildren... (obviously) She handles family matters.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: And what about you? Bella hesitates to answer. The other Women all look up fr their work with big smiles at this question.

dialogues.speaker: DONATELLA
dialogues.text: Anything to do with love...

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Bella is our romantic...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Our hopeless romantic...

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: At least I'm some kind of romantic. Sophia is still trying to get her head around all of it.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: So? Who pays for all this?  18.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: We're all volunteers. We pitch in what we can when we need to. Bella nods. Sophia is blown away.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Wow. Maria walks over with the basket of letters Bella collect

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: We're gonna start reading. Bella notices Sophia looking curiously at the letters.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Would you like to help?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Oh. No. I shouldn't. I couldn't. I'm not much of an expert on love or romance or... Bella gently places a letter written in English in her ha

dialogues.text: "Dear Juliet, how do you know when you're in love? Can you know?..."

dialogues.speaker: AUSTRALIAN WOMAN V/O
dialogues.text: ",..duliet, I don't think I want to marry him but I so want to get married. What should I do?..."  19.

dialogues.text: "...Is it weird to think sex is gross? I mean cause it kinda is, right? I'm not like weird for thinking that am I?..." Sophia places the teen's letter in one of several piles.

dialogues.text: The letters have been read and sorted. The Secretaries ar busy composing their responses - all by hand. Sophia sits watching Bella write.

dialogues.text: Do you ever worry about being wrong?

dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: You're giving answers but how do you know they're the right answers? Bella considers the question for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: We don't tell anyone what to do, we just share our experiences, we let them know they're not alone. There are no wrong right or wrong answers when you write from your heart. Sophia smiles at that sentiment.

dialogues.text: Bobby has excused himself from an editor's meeting to tak call. The look on his face tell us he regrets doing so.

dialogues.text: Well. Yeah. No. I'd probably focus more on their moving, self-less attempts to... spread hope, and answer love's unanswered questions. Bobby considers for a beat - a beat more than usual. Befo

dialogues.text: It's not a feature. There's no hook. Get me a hook then maybe, just maybe, I'll let you go fishing... And Sophia?

dialogues.text: (hopeful) Yeah?

dialogues.text: Next time you call it better be to find out what kind of wine I like.

dialogues.text: Sophia sits at a table with her laptop open. She's glarin that cursor blinking on that blank document. Bella approaches with a huge bowl of pasta topped with steaming meatballs in a tomato sauce.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I didn't order...

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: My mother's meatballs, they're legendary. Just a little thank you for your help last night.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: "Little"? Victor approaches carrying the Verona guide book, smiling

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Supplier meetings are officially done. I am all yours as promised. (he kisses her) You want to check out that Museo... whatever it's called?  21. Sophia turns to Bella.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Victor, this is Bella, she's one of The Secretaries I told you about. Bella smiles at Victor but he's not looking at her just n He's caught a scent.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What's that smell? He looks at the plate in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Victor? He picks up her plate and sticks his nose very close to i and inhales deeply. He's staggered by the aroma.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: My God. He grabs her fork and tastes. He groans with pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: You like?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: D'you know what's in this?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Oregano, garlic, parsley, bread... He shakes his head "no" then pauses for effect.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: History. Years and years, generations and generations, of history. Who made this?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Her mother.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: I have to meet her. Victor goes without waiting for Bella who looks at Sophia curiously then follows him. Sophia is alone at the table. She looks at the meatballs suspiciously then tastes one.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: That's a good meatball.  22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia's plate is long since empty. She looks at it and t at her watch. She gets up and heads back towards the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finds Victor in chef's whites cooking with Angelina. looks up at Sophia as she walks in.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Have you met Angelina?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I have.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: She's a genius.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: She is.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELINA
dialogues.text: He's such a charmer.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Isn't he just? (holds up the guide book) So? You about ready to go? He hesitates. Victor treads lightly around the following:

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure, here's the thing though, Angelina's offered to let me work a dinner service with her tonight. She's gonna teach me to make that marinara. Can you imagine that marinara in Manhattan? Sophia is clearly annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: And what am I supposed to do? Bella steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: You could always help us. Victor jumps all over this suggestion.  23.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Great idea. That is a great idea. You write. I'll cook. Win-win. Sophia just looks at him, thinks about arguing, then does

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia and Bella gather up the day's letters in silence. Sophia is clearly still miffed about Victor bailing on he

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Your Victor is very... passionate.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: About food. My Victor is very passionate about food. This revelation unsettles Bella she looks like she wants say something more but stops herself. They finish collecting and are headed out when Sophia not a letter they missed stuck on a remote corner of the wall

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Forgot one. Sophia jogs back to get it when she pulls it from the anc wall, a large piece of mortar falls at her feet. She look back at Bella as if to "sorry." Bella shrugs it off.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: It happens. Sophia picks up the piece of mortar and tries to slide it back in place when something catches her eye hidden deep within the newly made crack in the wall. It looks like pa Sophia slides her fingers into the crack. She manages to the paper and pull it out. She stares in amazement. CLOSE ON: An envelope. It's old and stained. The writing quaintly old fashioned in that spidery kind of way.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA O/S
dialogues.text: Look at the date...

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: 1951! My God.  24. The Secretaries are gathered around Sophia who is holding old handwritten letter.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: What does it say?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: "I didn't go to him, Juliet. I didn't go to Alfonso. I was on holiday with my parents; he was a local boy, he picked grapes at a vineyard. It was his eyes. I still remember the first time those eyes found me. My parents would never approve so we made plans to run away. We were supposed to meet at that vineyard but when the time came, I couldn't bring myself to go. My parents and I returned to London the next morning. I'm so afraid. I fear the only thing worse than not being with him would be knowing he doesn't want to be with me. Please, tell me what to do. With love, Claire Smith." Silence. Sophia just stares at the letter, affected.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: I think she came back. She flew in the face of her parents and her friends to find her one true love. And she made sweet love to her Alfonso for the rest of her life.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: I think she found him. They had ten children. Then he got old and bald and fat and she wonders every day what happened to that gorgeous Romeo she left her family for.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: I think she stayed in England where she married a Duke and lived happily ever after in his castle...

dialogues.speaker: DONATELLA
dialogues.text: And I'll bet when she's making love to that Duke she's imagining her first love. I do that all the time. Everyone laughs except Sophia who's still holding the let  25.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I'd like to write back. The women all stop laughing and look at her.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: Why? She's probably moved.

dialogues.speaker: DONATELLA
dialogues.text: Or died.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Probably moved and died.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Probably. But she wanted an answer. Bella smiles at this she gives Sophia a pen and paper.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: So give her one.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: SHOTS OF: The Secretaries quietly going about reading and replying to that day's batch of letters efficiently. They write dozens of different letters throughout the nig But Sophia works only on that one letter to Claire Smith. chooses each word carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Secretaries have left for the evening. Only Bella and Sophia remain. Bella looks over her shoulder at Sophia's letter - it's rather long at this point.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Let's hope if she gets it she has some time on her hands.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Too long?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: No... (smiles) -..-not for a novella. Bella puts on her coat and heads out the door.  26.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Lock the door and turn off the lights when you're done, OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia has finally finished the letter. She's addresses t envelope and puts on a stamp. She stretches, yawns. There knock at the door. Sophia turns to find Victor coming in a plate of anti pasti. She smiles. He smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Hey you. He sets down the plate of food and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: You have fun playing secretary?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I did actually. I forgot what it was like to just write. It was nice.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: I'm glad.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: How'd it go with Angelina?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: It was unreal. I thought I was good but she's outta my league. She cooks from feel. No measurements, no timers, no prep, everything's fresh, she's incredible. I could learn a lot from her in a week... Silence as he lets that last sentence just hang there. So realizes what he's asking, why he brought her the anti pa She stops eating it and just looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: You promised this trip wouldn't just be about the restaurant?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: I know. I know I did. But this is a chance to learn sixty years of culinary knowledge in a week. It's a once-in-a-life time opportunity for me - for us...  27. Sophia sighs.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: But I haven't said yes yet. And I did promise you. So? If you say don't do it, I won't do it. Sophia knows she can't tell him not to.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Is that OK like it's really not OK?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: It's just OK. That's good enough. He kisses her. She tries to smile. He puts his arm around her as they walk to the door. Soph turns the light off and drops her letter in the out box.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. VERONA. VARIOUS OF
dialogues.text: Sophia exploring the streets of Verona. She walks across the Roman Ponte Pietro to look at the ri She shops in a street market in the centre of the city. She tours the Verona Arena and the Museo Castelvecchio. She eats dinner with Victor and Angelina. Victor is chatt up Angelina about the food. Sophia sits quietly sipping w She walks down the chic Via Mazzini casually window-brows all the boutiques. She has a few carrier bags in her hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor enjoys himself in the kitchen amongst all the nois and chaos. He's chopping, stirring, tasting, the guy swea enthusiasm. He tastes a bowl of meatballs and marinara, n his satisfaction, then refuses to let the WAITER take the out.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: No, no. I'll do it. Victor picks up the bowl, makes the sign of the cross, th should barges his way out into the restaurant where...  28. The Secretaries of Juliet are sitting at a long table wit Angelina, drinking wine and laughing loudly. Victor proudly places the bowl of meatballs in the middle the table and then declares in his best flawed Italian:

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Ladies, I give you my balls. There is a pause before the women burst out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Please, help yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: If were thirty years younger I would. The women laugh again and start serving them out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Attempting Angelina's meatballs... either very brave or very stupid. They all taste them, adjudicating as they chew. For Victo this is sheer agony. All eyes are on Angelina. It seems l an eternity before she starts to slowly nod her head approvingly. The others follow suit and start clapping. Victor is so overcome that he sweeps Angelina into his ar and kisses the old woman passionately on the lips. Everyo cheers. Angelina is quite flustered and flushed by the ki

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I remember when he used to have that effect on me. Bella laughs and stands up tapping her wine glass.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: To our new friends. Who leave us tomorrow as they continue onto Palermo but will remain in our hearts. To Victor and Sophia. Everyone raises their glass.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: To Victor and Sophia! They clink and drink. Victor takes in the moment. He smil at Sophia like someone trying to keep a secret who can't.  29.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Sophia? She turns to see him smiling big at her.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: I want you to be my front of house.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Your what? Victor theatrically drops to one knee - playing to the cr

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: (takes her hand) Will you be my front of house? A beat of confusion.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Is that like code or a metaphor or something?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: I want you to run the restaurant. She just stares at him - flabbergasted. He stands up.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: What about my job?

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: You hate your job.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: But I love writing. I still want to write. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: You always talk about taking a step forward, making a change, this is a change.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I was thinking more like a change to The New Yorker not Zagats. Silence. This isn't going how Victor has envisioned.  30.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: I want us to do this together. It won't be the same without you. Sophia doesn't know what to say or where to look. She jus stares at him speechless. Before she can answer a subtly handsome Englishman enters the restaurant. He is CHARLIE.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I'm sorry to interrupt, but are you the Secretaries of Juliet?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: You found them.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Great. So which one of you wrote this letter to my grandmother, Claire Smith? Sophia can't believe it. How fantastic! She steps forward

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I wrote it.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It was a very thoughtful letter.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Now if you wouldn't mind telling me what the hell you were thinking? A deathly silence. This is not what she was expecting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia and Charlie sit at table removed from the others. Victor is visible in the background serving The Secretari

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: She deserved an answer.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Fifty seven years ago maybe. Not now.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Why not?  31.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Because she was a fifteen-year-old girl then. She's a seventy-two-year-— old woman now.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I can do math. Math is not a reason not to write a letter.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It was a teenage infatuation, a holiday romance, can you imagine what could've happened if she hadn't seen sense?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Well you wouldn't be here, I mean at all. Which I'd have to say would be an upside.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What good did you think could possibly come from writing her that letter?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: What harm could come from it? Pause as they eye each other up.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: So that's it? You came all the way from England to give me a lecture, I'm impressed. Or did you just happen to be in town?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, I came because I couldn't let my grandmother come on her own.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Claire's here? Why?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I think even you might be able to work that one out.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Oh my God, she's come to find her Alfonso, that's awesome, I want to meet her.  32.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I want to play for Manchester United but I'm shit at football.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: You honestly don't think she'd want to meet me?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I honestly think she has no interest in meeting a woman who can Manage to jam "oh my God" and "awesome" into the same sentence.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Did you ask her?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It just wouldn't occur to her.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Where are you staying?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (laughs) D'you really think I'm that stupid?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I haven't decided yet. A beat. Charlie gets up from the table.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Why did you come here tonight?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I was just curious to see what kind of imbecile would think writing that letter was such a great idea. I should've known it'd be an American. Good night. He strides out of the restaurant. Sophia is appalled at h rudeness and is stuck to her chair for a moment. She looks across the room at Victor serving The Secretari their entrees. They applaud his efforts. He's beaming. Sophia thinks for a beat. Then grabs her coat and leaves.  33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia emerges from the restaurant and looks around to se which way Charlie has gone. She spots him and starts to follow him at a discreet distance. At one point he gets the feeling he's being followed and stops. He quickly turns around just as Sophia ducks into shop doorway. Finally he arrives at his hotel and heads inside. Sophia waits for a moment before heading in herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia waits as the RECEPTIONIST looks something up on a computer screen.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Claire Smith - room 32.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia walks down the hallway to room 32. She's nervous a she takes a deep breath and knocks on the door. She adjus her hair and straightens her dress. The door opens. And h face drops as she is confronted by Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (whispers) What the bloody hell are you doing here? He moves out pulling the door semi-closed behind him.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I think maybe even you can work that one out.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I told you she doesn't want to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: You told me it wouldn't occur to her to want to meet me. A voice comes from inside the room.  34.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE 0/S
dialogues.text: Who is it Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: (shouts) My name is Sophia. I wrote the letter.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE 0/S
dialogues.text: Well for goodness sake come in. Charlie looks daggers at her then reluctantly opens the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia walks into the room and there she is, CLAIRE SMITH regal beauty at the age of seventy two. She gets up and f fleeting moment, bathed in a Veronese backlight, she almo looks like the fifteen year old who sent that letter all those years ago. They take each other’s hand and don’t let go. They take a long look at each other - so many questions on either sid

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: You look like I thought you'd look.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Since you wrote to a fifteen-year- old I'll take that as a compliment. Sophia smiles. Claire smiles. Charlie isn't smiling.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: How did you find us?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Charlie found me, actually. Claire turns to Charlie who shrugs as if to say "surprise

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: He told me you were here and said you might like to meet me.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: How uncharacteristically thoughtful of you dear. Slight pause. He looks at Sophia who smiles innocently.  35.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, in the circumstances, it seemed a little churlish not to meet the person responsible for this voyage of lunacy.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Charlie doesn’t approve. Which makes it all the more fun. Would you like some tea? Oh no, of course, you’re American. We'll order coffee. Charlie? He obediently goes to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all sit having coffee while Claire talks.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I waited for a reply to that letter for two years. Once I even plucked up the courage to run away and find him. But it only lasted as far as Waterloo Station, I’m afraid.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So why is it you never mentioned him to me till last week then?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: It was such a long time ago, dear. And I met your grandfather and over the years I did my best to forget that summer in Tuscany and the bronzed Adonis of a boy who kissed me for the first time. He was the first person to ever tell me I was beautiful. And boy did it sound more romantic in Italian.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I'll bet.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: “Clara, siete cosi bella.”

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: But you and Gramps were happy enough, weren’t you?  36.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: That's exactly right - happy enough. We were a “good couple” with much to be grateful for. Except for you Charlie, you’ve been the bane of my existence. Sophia smiles, intrigued by these two.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Then when Jack died - there’s a lot of Jack in Charlie, funnily enough - I grieved profoundly for years. But as time went by his memory became a distant, warm glow, instead of a searing pain in my side. Then, unexpectedly, at odd hours of the day, in my dreams at night, I found myself thinking about Alfonso... which made it all the more extraordinary when, out of the blue, your letter arrived. I’m so grateful you wrote it. There were so many reasons not to.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'll say.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: So what happens now?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Well the thing is, I think we've found him.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Really? Where?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Just outside Verona. Quite close to where he used to live, actually.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: No! That's incredible.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Charlie thinks it's a dreadful mistake.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: It'll be fine, really it will. Sophia looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry. I have to go. I'm flying down to Palermo with my boyfriend for a few days before we go home. He’s found some kind of weird cheese down there.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (slightly disappointed) Of course you are. Thank you so much for the letter. 37. They hug. Sophia turns to Charlie who extends his hand stiffly.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It's been a pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I guess your idea of pleasure and mine are two very different things. For a moment he seems charmed by her directness and hones He smiles. Claire gives her a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: My phone number back in London. Will you call me?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I will. I have to know how it ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia and Victor are in the middle of packing Sophia's head is still in Claire's hotel room.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: for Palermo. Victor is focused intently on packing, he's not really listening.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I so hope it works out for her...

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I mean imagine if they found each other after fifty years...

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: That'd be something.  38.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Because I found a letter in a wall, it's crazy, it's like no story that's ever been told...

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Right. Sophia pauses on this thought. Then the penny drops.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I have to write it.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: You can start on the plane.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I have to stay. Victor's listening now.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Wait. What?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I have to know out how it ends.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What about Palermo? The cheese?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: You don't need me for cheese. You can pick me up on your way back. I'll write. You taste. Win win. Sophia starts unpacking her suitcase. Victor stammers.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Can't we at least discuss this?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I started it. I have to finish it.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: But? Who are these people? You're just gonna go off with them? They could be serial killers...

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Killers who oh-so-cleverly planted a half century old love letter ina wall for me to find. How devious.  39. She smiles, keeps unpacking. Victor just stands there rac his brain for a reason she has to come with him.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: But? Who's gonna take the pictures?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia is walking through Claire's hotel on her cell phon

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I already have the title: "Does True Love Have a Shelf Life?" INTERCUT: Bobby in his office on the phone with Sophia. H eating Chinese food as he scrolls through and answers e-m

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You can't actually think she'll find this guy? A hundred bucks says he's dead, married or gay.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: But what if he's not? What if she does? What if that spark is still there after fifty years? He can't. He nods to himself. Takes a bite of an egg roll

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Could be something there.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: So I should write it?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You can write it. Doesn't mean I'll print it. Sophia smiles - good enough for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia is standing at Claire's door. Charlie opens it.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Hi!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh God.  40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia, Claire and Charlie walk through the streets towar Juliet’s house. Charlie casts a disbelieving glance at So - What is she doing here?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Alfonso had such a way with plants. Working those fields was spiritual for him. He'd always talk about the land in Tuscany, the way it smelled, the moisture in the soil, perfect for the grapes he’d grow there one day. He used to say all he needed to be happy were days in those fields and nights with me. Sophia smiles at this.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: When he was working I’d pray for the sun to come out because then he'd have to take off his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Nana!

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: He was so solid and brown. The sweat would glisten off his back like little jewels. The thought of it still sends shivers down my spine.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Alright, I think we get the picture.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: What, you don't approve of your old Gran having carnal thoughts?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh for heaven's sake.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: You're such a prude. And you're ageist.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I am not! I love old people.  4l.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: So long as they're not thinking dirty thoughts. Charlie bristles. Before he can think of a deft reply...

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Here we are. They walk into Juliet’s courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Gosh, I remember this so well. We were on our way home. I was so sad. Then I looked up at her an thought - she'd know what to do. I'll ask her.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Sorry it took her so long to get back to you. Claire smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: No matter. I'm here now. A familiar voice comes from behind them.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA 0/S
dialogues.text: Is this her? Sophia turns and finds Bella holding a basket of the day' letters. Bella is looking at Claire.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Claire. This is Bella. She's one of The Secretaries.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Ah yes, another interfering busybody. Perfect. Neither Bella nor Claire pay him any mind. They smile.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: It's such a pleasure to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: And such an honor to meet you. Claire goes to shake her hand but Bella grabs her and hug her and kisses her on both cheeks.  42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire is the guest of honor at the head of a table with Charlie, Sophia and the rest of The Secretaries. They're eating dinner. The Secretaries are all smiling at Claire.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Are you nervous?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: A bit I suppose. What if I’ve turned him into something he isn’t? He’s always existed in my mind’s eye as a model of perfection. Like a ‘57 Bentley Continental. What if he’s actually a clapped out old Alfa Romeo with bundles of nose hair? What if he doesn’t remember me at all - if I was simply not to him what he was to me? Slight pause as they all think about this. Charlie wades

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Right. Let’s go home then before it all ends in tears.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: What is it with you? It's like you really don't want this to work out. Charlie is aghast at such a suggestion - a little too agh

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'm a realist not a fantasist, that's the point.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: No it's not. The point is you're English.

dialogues.speaker: MARIA
dialogues.text: No romance.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCESCA
dialogues.text: Lots of cynicism.

dialogues.speaker: DONATELLA
dialogues.text: Cold as fish.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You don't have to be a cold fish to think the idea of true love lasting forever is ridiculous. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE (cont'd) Actually, come to that, the very idea of true love at all leaves one struggling.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Well in that case we take it all back. Everyone laughs except Charlie. Claire smiles softly at h

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Charlie why don’t you get yourself out of the line of fire and settle the bill? He motions for the waiter to bring the bill. As soon as s sees this Angelina comes striding across the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: ANGELINA
dialogues.text: No charge.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry we couldn't possibly...

dialogues.speaker: ANGELINA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, you can possibly. He looks at her - realizes this isn’t someone you mess wi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Secretaries are walking with Claire, laughing and chatting. Charlie and Sophia follow at a short distance.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You know, I’m not the buttoned up, buttock clenching, killjoy you lot are trying to make me out to be.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Right. We made you argue that true love is ridiculous. Thanks for clearing that up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It's just that I am genuinely worried for her.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: She'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Physically yes. But what if he breaks her heart? What if he laughs in her face? What if he doesn’t remember her? Is it so unreasonable for me to worry about that?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: My gut says that'll never happen.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Then you really do have greater faith in mankind than I do. They walk on watching the women walking ahead. Sophia smi

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You really think it's possible two people can be apart for so long and pick up right where they left off? Sophia reflects on the question.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I don't know. I hope it is.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: To find out, I guess. (smiles) Plus I think I've got a bit of a crush on your grandmother. He looks at her slightly disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia sits at a desk with her laptop open. She starts to type. Stops for a moment. She closes the laptop. Somethin doesn't feel right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia, Claire and Charlie are loading up the rental car.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Before we go anywhere I need to be straight with you both. My being here is not entirely selfless. It started as that. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOPHIA (cont'd) And I do want to help. But I’d also like to write an article about what happens. I want to tell your story, Claire.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: A bloody journalist! I should've known.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Hardly. I'm a fact checker. I've never had a word published.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And you think Gran's story is your ticket to being published. Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I think her story is a story worth telling. Claire smiles her approval.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Well I think that’s simply marvellous. We both get something out of it. It’s a what d’you call it? A win win. Sophia smiles appreciatively.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m so pleased for you both but where, exactly, do I fit in?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, dear. Every story needs a comedy character. She gets into the car. Sophia smiles at Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: This is going to write itself. Something starts buzzing in her bag. She fishes around in and brings out her cell phone. She grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I missed Victor. I had it on silent all night. He's probably frantic.  46.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I would be. I’d have probably killed myself by now - in a most violent manner leaving a poignant note which would haunt you forever.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE 0/S
dialogues.text: (from inside the car) Charlie! Sophia can't help but smile at Charlie as she dials Victo

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I hope he's not too worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor's looking anything but worried as he's enthralled an assortment of samples of a stocky CHEESE MAKER'S fines Italian cheeses. He's a kid in a candy store. He tastes s fresh made pecorino romano. It leaves him speechless. His Black berry - set on silent - is flashing on his belt buckle. CLOSE ON: The Display. The ID reads: "Sophia"

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: Sophia putting her phone away and getting in the car with Charlie and Claire.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Was he frantic?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I couldn't get him. He's probably out in the country out of range.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Or he's working on that note. Claire smacks Charlie on the top of his head. Sophia laug

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: How about you? Is there some lucky girl who makes you frantic?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: There is one - was one - until recently, Patricia. But the less said about her the better... so currently, no, I am without “frantic” in my life and the sense of relief is palpable.  47.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: For everyone I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. CAR, (DRIVING)
dialogues.text: They travel towards Arezzo, Charlie driving, Claire besid him and Sophia in the back leaning forward between the se

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Victor used to work at this little Italian place in The City. I'd go there to work every week. I'd get a double espresso and a water - no ice. And he'd come by my table, tell jokes, make small talk. Then one week he bought my espresso, a week later he bought me lunch, then dinner, a week after that he cooked me dinner at his place, and three months later I moved in with him.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: How romantic. With a longing that tells us this was as romantic as it g

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Yeah... it was...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: So you live with a waiter then.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Charlie you're such a snob.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I am not. He might have been a bus boy.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: He's a chef actually. A talented one. He's opening his own place... (slight pause) It's gonna be great, I know it. He won't let it be anything else.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Sounds like quite a catch. Your mother must be pleased.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I'm sure she would be.  48. Claire looks worried she's made a dreadful assumption.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Oh dear. Has she passed on then?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Moved on is more accurate. She left when I was little.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: (shrugging it off) Don't be. I'm not. Charlie looks at her in the rear view mirror as she stare out of the window and sees that nothing could be further the truth as she displays a rare moment of vulnerability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car stops at a narrow country road in front of an old farmhouse surrounded by meadows and olive groves. Claire, Sophia, and Charlie look at the old house through car window. Claire doesn’t move. Sophia takes her hand an gives it a squeeze. Claire smiles then gets out of the ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trio approaches the door. Charlie glances at Claire. nods yes. Charlie reluctantly knocks on the door. They wa moment. Nothing. He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No one in. Come on. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Charlie?! He takes Claire’s hand and starts for the car. Then the d opens. They stop and turn as ALFONSO appears at the door. he’s 73, dark and ruggedly handsome. Sophia and Charlie g

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (in fluent Italian) Are you Alfonso De Annunzio? The man nods. Charlie and Sophia exchange a glance - we'v found him! - but alas Claire knows immediately that:  49.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: That's not him.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: It's not him.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: But he looks...

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: It's the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Do you remember what you were doing in the summer of 1951?

dialogues.speaker: ALFONSO
dialogues.text: (smiles wistfully) Ah, the summer of 1951, I'll never forget it, I met the most beautiful girl with long, brown hair...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Nana! But Claire has already turned away, disappointed, and is walking towards the car.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: They're not his eyes. It's not him.

dialogues.speaker: ALFONSO
dialogues.text: We married that year ... and she gave me nothing but trouble from that day on! I curse that woman!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Right... He and Sophia follow Claire to the car as Alfonso continu raving from his doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: ALFONSO
dialogues.text: I curse her eyes! I curse her teeth! I curse her mustache! They get into the car. A beat of silence.  50.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Right, well that's that. We gave it a fair shot. Can't say we didn't try. Sorry Nana. Truly.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Are you for real?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: If I actually knew what that question meant, I might attempt to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: He can’t be the only Alfonso De Annunzio in Tuscany.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: He's the only one around here. Are you suggesting we knock on the doors of every Alfonso we can find?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Are you suggesting we don't? Charlie looks at Claire. It's obvious she wants to keep looking. Charlie sighs as if to say "Fine".

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: This is madness. Total madness.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: How many can there be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire is lying on a sun bed in the shade. Charlie swims relentlessly up and down the pool - quite clearly for exercise rather than pleasure. Sophia sits at a nearby ta working away at her laptop. She finishes typing.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Thirty six.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: That many? Claire sighs. Sophia has an idea.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I might be able to find some pictures online. Give me a minute.  51. At this point Charlie hauls himself out of the pool. He h surprisingly well toned body. This guy obviously works ou Sophia can’t help but notice.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: (quietly to herself) Whoa. She sees Claire smiling at her. She blushes.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Did I just say that out loud?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I believe “ripped” is the appropriate modern term isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: (smiling) Ok, here we go, I've found photos of two of them. Claire takes a look and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: No. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: So that leaves us with thirty four.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (approaching) Thirty four what?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Contestants for Italian Idol.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Fantastic! He walks away drying himself off.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Is he really unhappy about this or just pretending?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: A bit of both I think. Claire watches Sophia working on her laptop as if weighin whether she’s going to ask her what’s on her mind.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Tell me about your mother.  52.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: (without looking up) Nothing to tell.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Indulge a nosy old lady. Slight beat. Sophia looks at this woman with such kind ey and sees someone who genuinely wants to know.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: There’s nothing much to say really. I was young. I don't remember much. Then one day she just upped and left. Just like that. No warning, no note, no forwarding address, not even a goodbye or good luck.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: How old were you?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I was ten.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: And you haven't seen her since?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Don't expect I ever will.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: That must've been very hard. Sophia shrugs as if to say "not really".

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I started packing my own lunches, probably ironed a few more of my dad's shirts than I would have.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: You don't ever think about trying to find her?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I used to. Until I realized that she didn’t feel like she could waste her time on me so why should I waste a minute of mine on her? Sophia looks down in an attempt to control her feelings. Claire takes her hand and gives it a squeeze.  53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three of them are having dinner.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Charlie have you told Sophia about the Green Alliance?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Can't imagine she'd care.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Try me.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Charlie’s going to stand for parliament on the environment ticket. Sophia looks genuinely surprised.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You know the kind of thing - planting trees, air fare taxes, bicycle lanes, eliminating cars from Central London - great idea, pity it doesn’t stand a chance, really.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: That's amazing.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You look surprised.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I guess I am. I didn't have you pinned as a "Save the planet" type.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: And what type did you have me pinned down for, exactly?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I don't know. I was leaning towards the "elitist Oxford prig" type but now that you mention it "self- satisfied do gooder" fits too.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well thank you very much. Sophia laughs. So does Charlie. Claire smiles at this.  54.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Oh don’t be fooled by all the posturing he’s just a little teddy bear really. She ruffles up his hair.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Get off!

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: He’s still trying to work out our carbon print for this little jaunt.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Anther good reason not to have come.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: He’ll have me planting trees for months. (she yawns) Well I'm off to my bed. You two be nice to each other now. She kisses them both on the head and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: She's incredible.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah she's alright. But with her gone it seems they have nothing to talk abou So they just sit there in silence. A pantomime of embarrassment. An exchange of awkward smiles. Then finall

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Right. Well. Time to hit the sack. Sophia smiles she knows he's just trying to get out of th

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: It must be at least nine thirty.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Long day tomorrow. Need my rest and all that.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Oh of course.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Right. Alright. Good night then.  55. He gets up and strides off leaving her at the table. Then stops in the entrance. His back is turned to her for a mo then he swivels round and marches straight back.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Forgive me. Where are my manners?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I have absolutely no idea.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what it is, but you seem to bring out the very worst in me.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I figured it’d be my fault somehow.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Please, may I buy you a night cap? A beat. She smiles politely.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: No thanks. I'm tired.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Right. Of course. Apologies.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Accepted. He stands there for a minute, unsure what to do.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well. Good night then. Again.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: Good night Charlie.

dialogues.text: They are with a sweet looking PRIEST, dressed in cassock hat, outside his church. He is holding both of Claire’s h as he shakes his head gently. He is not her Alfonso. Then makes the sign of the cross over Claire as a blessing.

dialogues.text: They drive a tree-lined street to a gorgeous stately Pala

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You sure we've got the right address? Sophia double checks.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: This is the place.  57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are talking to a very handsome, beautifully dressed groomed Italian man. This guy is probably a COUNT. He sha his head. Claire smiles.

dialogues.speaker: COUNT
dialogues.text: Alas it wasn’t me. If it had been I'd’ve never let you go. And with that he kisses her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk towards the car. Claire is still slightly flush

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: What is it with you and Italian men? They just fall at your feet. Charlie takes one last look at the Palazzo. He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Such a shame. I think I could’ve been happy here. Sophia and Claire exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia, Claire, and Charlie wait patiently and quietly in waiting room. Sophia is trying to stay upbeat but the sig of so many ill and lonely OLD PEOPLE has definitely lower the mood of all three. A NURSE comes to them holding the arm of yet another ALFO a sweet man, bald, wearing sunglasses, with a bright smil He walks right up to Claire.

dialogues.speaker: ALFONSO
dialogues.text: Your face... it is so familiar... Sophia and Charlie exchange a hopeful glance.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Alfonso, this is Claire, do you remember Claire?

dialogues.speaker: ALFONSO
dialogues.text: Claire! Of course. Of course.  58. Alfonso takes off his sunglasses to get a better look at Sophia and Charlie instantly look at Claire. It’s not him

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: (quietly) Shit... He's confused her for someone else. Claire plays along so not to hurt the sweet old man's feelings. She hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: It was good to see you, Alfonso.

dialogues.speaker: ALFONSO
dialogues.text: You too, my angel. Thanks for visiting! Come back soon! He waves to them as they go - they made his day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk to the car in silence.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That’s it for today I think.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: One more?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: She’s exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: I am. Sophia sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophia is on her cell in her room. Her notebook is open o the desk next to her laptop. She’s clearly been working o the story. The remains of her dinner are on a plate nearb

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIA
dialogues.text: I hope we’re doing the right thing. She’s so full of hope one minute then deflated the next. The ups and downs are killing me, I can't imagine what's it like for her...  59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor has a Bluetooth ear piece in. He's paying close attention to every detail about how the restaurant is run and not paying any attention to what Sophia is saying. Th
